title: Communication Styles
description: Discover how you each prefer to share and receive information.

questions.text: How do I prefer to communicate important things to you?
choices: Face-to-face conversation
During a walk or activity
In the moment as they happen
After I've had time to think

therapeutic.rationale: Communication medium matters more than we realize. Face-to-face allows for full presence; walking reduces intensity; in-the-moment sharing is spontaneous and raw; thinking first enables thoughtful delivery. Partners who prefer different channels may miss or misinterpret important messages.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different communication channels can cause friction. The face-to-face person may feel dismissed by indirect communication; the think-first person may feel overwhelmed by immediate demands. Adapt to your partner's receiving channel for important conversations.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared communication channels mean important conversations will flow naturally. You'll both be comfortable with the same medium.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you prefer to share important news? Does your partner communicate important things the way you'd prefer to receive them? What channel works best for you?

questions.text: What's my communication style when I'm upset?
choices: I need to talk it out immediately
I need space before I can discuss it
I get quiet and withdraw
I become more direct and assertive

therapeutic.rationale: Upset communication patterns often reflect attachment styles formed early in life. Immediate talkers process externally and need verbal connection; space-needers must self-regulate first; withdrawers protect themselves through distance; assertive communicators become more direct under stress. These patterns often clash when partners differ.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different upset styles cause significant conflict escalation. The immediate talker may chase the withdrawer; the space-needer feels smothered by the pursuer. Learn each other's patterns: 'When I'm upset, I need X before we can talk productively.'
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched upset styles make conflict more manageable. You'll naturally give each other what's needed during tense moments.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What happens to you when you're upset? What do you need before you can talk about it? Does your partner understand your pattern?

questions.text: How do I prefer you to communicate with me when you're upset?
choices: Tell me directly what's wrong
Take some time to process first
Express your feelings calmly
Let me know you need space

therapeutic.rationale: How we prefer our partner to share their upset differs from our own upset style. Some prefer directness—just tell me; others need calm—not emotional intensity; others appreciate processing time; others want heads-up on space-taking. Knowing your partner's receiving preferences helps you share your upset in ways they can hear.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different receiving preferences for upset partners mean your natural sharing style may not land well. The direct-preferrer feels confused by hints; the calm-preferrer feels overwhelmed by intensity. Adjust how you share upset based on how your partner receives it.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared receiving preferences mean your upset communication will be received as intended. You both want the same approach when the other is distressed.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When your partner is upset with you, what helps you hear them? What makes you defensive? What would make receiving their upset easier?

questions.text: What's the best way for you to get my attention when I'm distracted?
choices: Gently touch my arm or shoulder
Say my name and wait for eye contact
Wait for a natural break in what I'm doing
Just start talking—I'll catch up

therapeutic.rationale: Attention-getting preferences reflect boundaries and processing styles. Touch-preferrers are physically responsive; name-callers need full focus before continuing; break-waiters need completion; start-talkers can split attention. Partners who interrupt in unwanted ways create small daily friction that accumulates.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different attention-getting preferences can cause minor but repeated irritation. The touch-preferrer may startle the name-caller; the break-waiter may feel ignored by the start-talker. Small accommodations in how you get attention prevent daily friction.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared attention-getting preferences mean interruptions will feel natural rather than jarring. You'll both appreciate the same approach.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you prefer to be interrupted when focused on something? What approach annoys you? Does your partner know what works?

questions.text: How do I prefer to be asked to do something?
choices: Direct request with reasons why
Gentle suggestion or question
Through appreciation for past help
With advance notice when possible

therapeutic.rationale: Request styles affect compliance and resentment. Direct-with-reasons satisfies those who need context; gentle suggestion feels less demanding; appreciation-first acknowledges prior contribution; advance notice respects scheduling. Asking in the wrong way can make even willing partners resistant.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different request preferences can create unnecessary friction. The direct-with-reasons person may feel controlled by advance-notice requests; the appreciation-first person may feel taken for granted by direct requests. Match your asking style to your partner's preference.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared request preferences mean asking for things will feel natural and respectful. You'll both appreciate the same approach to requests.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes you want to say yes when your partner asks for something? What makes you resistant? Does your partner know how to ask in ways that work for you?
